Question 4: Why do bottlenose dolphins sleep unihemispherically? Options: A. To conserve energy, B. To stay alert to threats, C. To keep their newborn calf safe, D. To migrate at sea Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the type of sleep exhibited by frigatebirds during non-stop transoceanic flights? Options: A. Asymmetrical sleep, B. Unihemispheric sleep, C. Deep sleep, D. Light sleep Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the "first night effect" in humans? Options: A. A preference for deep sleep, B. A preference for light sleep, C. A subtle version of asymmetrical sleep, D. A type of sleep deprivation Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why do scientists often toss out the first night's data in sleep studies? Options: A. Because it's a normal for participants to sleep poorly their first night in the lab, B. Because it's a type of sleep deprivation, C. Because it's a rare type of sleep, D. Because it's a type of sleep disorder Correct Option: None

Asymmetrical sleep is a type of deep sleep, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of light sleep, B. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of sleep where one hemisphere is awake, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of sleep where both hemispheres are awake, C. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of sleep where both hemispheres are asleep, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of sleep where one hemisphere is awake and the other is asleep Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Many animals need sleep. Even brainless jellyfish enter 
sleep-like states where they pulse less and respond more slowly 
to food and movement. But all of the threats and demands 
animals face don’t just go away when it’s time to doze. That’s why a range of birds and mammals 
experience some degree of asymmetrical sleep where parts 
of their brain are asleep and other areas are more active. This is even true for humans. So how does it work? All vertebrate brains consist 
of two hemispheres: the right and left. Brain activity is usually similar 
across both during sleep. But during asymmetrical sleep, one brain hemisphere can be in deep sleep
while the other is in lighter sleep. And in an extreme version 
called “unihemispheric sleep,” one hemisphere may appear completely awake
while the other is in deep sleep. Take bottlenose dolphins. Their breathing is consciously controlled, and they must surface for air every 
few minutes or they’ll drown. When they have a newborn calf, they must
actually swim nonstop for weeks in order to keep it safe. So dolphins sleep unihemispherically,
with just one hemisphere at a time. This allows them to continue swimming
and breathing while snoozing. Other marine mammals also
need asymmetrical sleep. Fur seals might spend weeks on end 
migrating at sea. They slip into unihemispheric sleep
while floating horizontally, holding their nostrils above the surface,
closing their upward-facing eye, and keeping their
downward-facing eye open. This may help them stay alert
to threats from the depths. Similar pressures keep birds
partially awake. Mallard ducks sleep in groups, but some
must inevitably be on the peripheries. Those ducks spend more time 
in unihemispheric sleep, with their outward-facing eyes open and their corresponding
brain hemispheres more active. Other birds have been shown to catch z’s
in midair migration. While undertaking non-stop transoceanic 
flights of up to 10 days, frigatebirds either sleep with one
or both hemispheres at a time. They do so in seconds-long bursts,
usually while riding air currents. But the frigatebirds still sleep 
less than 8% of what they would on land, suggesting a great tolerance
for sleep deprivation. It’s currently unclear whether
asymmetrical sleep packs the same benefits as sleep 
in both hemispheres and how this varies across species. In one experiment, fur seals relied 
on asymmetrical sleep while being constantly stimulated. But in recovery, they showed 
a strong preference for sleep across both hemispheres, suggesting that it was more restorative 
for them. Dolphins, on the other hand, have been observed to maintain high levels
of alertness for at least five days. By switching which hemisphere is awake, they get several hours of deep sleep 
in each hemisphere throughout a 24-hour period. This may be why unihemispheric sleep alone
meets their needs. So, what about humans? Have you ever woken up groggy after
your first night in a new place? Part of your brain might’ve spent
the night only somewhat asleep. For decades, scientists have recognized
that participants sleep poorly their first night in the lab. It’s actually customary to toss
out that night’s data. In 2016, scientists discovered 
that this “first night effect” is a very subtle version 
of asymmetrical sleep in humans. They saw that, during the first night, participants experience deeper sleep
in their right hemisphere and lighter sleep in their left. When exposed to infrequent sounds, that lighter sleeping left hemisphere
showed greater bumps in activity. Participants also woke up and responded
to infrequent sounds faster during the first night than 
when experiencing deep sleep in both hemispheres 
during nights following. This suggests that, like other animals, humans use asymmetrical sleep
for vigilance, specifically in unfamiliar environments. So, while your hotel room is obviously
not trying to eat you and you’re not going to die 
if you don’t continue moving, your brain is still keeping you alert. Just in case.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: People cannot sleep well when they participate in a sleep study for the first time. What is this phenomenon called?
Options: A. The environmental effect, B. The surprising effect, C. The novelty effect, D. The first-night effect
Correct Option: D

Question 7: Why do scientists often toss out the first night's data in sleep studies? Options: A. Because it's a normal for participants to sleep poorly their first night in the lab, B. Because it's a type of sleep deprivation, C. Because it's a rare type of sleep, D. Because it's a type of sleep disorder Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main purpose of asymmetrical sleep in humans? Options: A. To conserve energy, B. To stay alert to threats, C. To recover from sleep deprivation, D. To improve cognitive function Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which of the following is a benefit of unihemispheric sleep in dolphins? Options: A. It allows them to stay alert to threats, B. It allows them to conserve energy, C. It allows them to recover from sleep deprivation, D. It allows them to improve cognitive function Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main difference between asymmetrical sleep and unihemispheric sleep? Options: A. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of deep sleep, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of light sleep, B. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of sleep where one hemisphere is awake, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of sleep where both hemispheres are awake, C. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of sleep where parts of the brain are asleep, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of sleep where one hemisphere is asleep and the other is awake, D. **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In what situation do mallard ducks show unihemispheric sleep?
Options: A. When they sleep in a safe place, B. When they sleep in the middle of a group, C. When they sleep in the edge of a group, D. When they sleep in a familiar place
Correct Option: C

partially awake. Mallard ducks sleep in groups, but some
must inevitably be on the peripheries. Those ducks spend more time 
in unihemispheric sleep, with their outward-facing eyes open and their corresponding
brain hemispheres more active. Other birds have been shown to catch z’s
in midair migration. While undertaking non-stop transoceanic 
flights of up to 10 days, frigatebirds either sleep with one
or both hemispheres at a time. They do so in seconds-long bursts,
usually while riding air currents. But the frigatebirds still sleep 
less than 8% of what they would on land, suggesting a great tolerance
for sleep deprivation. It’s currently unclear whether
asymmetrical sleep packs the same benefits as sleep 
in both hemispheres and how this varies across species. In one experiment, fur seals relied 
on asymmetrical sleep while being constantly stimulated. But in recovery, they showed 
a strong preference for sleep across both hemispheres, suggesting that it was more restorative 
for them. Dolphins, on the other hand, have been observed to maintain high levels
of alertness for at least five days. By switching which hemisphere is awake, they get several hours of deep sleep 
in each hemisphere throughout a 24-hour period. This may be why unihemispheric sleep alone
meets their needs. So, what about humans? Have you ever woken up groggy after
your first night in a new place? Part of your brain might’ve spent
the night only somewhat asleep. For decades, scientists have recognized
that participants sleep poorly their first night in the lab. It’s actually customary to toss
out that night’s data. In 2016, scientists discovered 
that this “first night effect” is a very subtle version 
of asymmetrical sleep in humans. They saw that, during the first night, participants experience deeper sleep
in their right hemisphere and lighter sleep in their left. When exposed to infrequent sounds, that lighter sleeping left hemisphere
showed greater bumps in activity. Participants also woke up and responded
to infrequent sounds faster during the first night than 
when experiencing deep sleep in both hemispheres 
during nights following. This suggests that, like other animals, humans use asymmetrical sleep
for vigilance, specifically in unfamiliar environments. So, while your hotel room is obviously
not trying to eat you and you’re not going to die 
if you don’t continue moving, your brain is still keeping you alert. Just in case.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which animals are known to show unihemispheric sleep?
Options: A. Jelly fish, B. Humans, C. Bottlenose dolphin, D. All the vertebrate animals
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of sleep is exhibited by brainless jellyfish, where they pulse less and respond more slowly to food and movement? Options: A. Asymmetrical sleep, B. Unihemispheric sleep, C. Deep sleep, D. Sleep-like state Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following mammals experience asymmetrical sleep, where parts of their brain are asleep and other areas are more active? Options: A. Only dolphins, B. Only fur seals, C. Both dolphins and fur seals, D. All mammals Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the type of sleep where one hemisphere of the brain is awake while the other is in deep sleep? Options: A. Asymmetrical sleep, B. Unihemispheric sleep, C. Deep sleep, D. Light sleep Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why do bottlenose dolphins sleep unihemispherically? Options: A. To conserve energy, B. To stay alert to threats, C. To keep their newborn calf safe, D. To migrate at sea Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the type of sleep exhibited by frigatebirds during non-stop transoceanic flights? Options: A. Asymmetrical sleep, B. Unihemispheric sleep, C. Deep sleep, D. Light sleep Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the "first night effect" in humans? Options: A. A preference for deep sleep, B. A preference for light sleep, C. A subtle version of asymmetrical sleep, D. A type of sleep deprivation Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why do scientists often toss out the first night's data in sleep studies? Options: A. Because it's a normal for participants to sleep poorly their first night in the lab, B. Because it's a type of sleep deprivation, C. Because it's a rare type of sleep, D. Because it's a type of sleep disorder Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main purpose of asymmetrical sleep in humans? Options: A. To conserve energy, B. To stay alert to threats, C. To recover from sleep deprivation, D. To improve cognitive function Correct Option: None

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Many animals need sleep. Even brainless jellyfish enter 
sleep-like states where they pulse less and respond more slowly 
to food and movement. But all of the threats and demands 
animals face don’t just go away when it’s time to doze. That’s why a range of birds and mammals 
experience some degree of asymmetrical sleep where parts 
of their brain are asleep and other areas are more active. This is even true for humans. So how does it work? All vertebrate brains consist 
of two hemispheres: the right and left. Brain activity is usually similar 
across both during sleep. But during asymmetrical sleep, one brain hemisphere can be in deep sleep
while the other is in lighter sleep. And in an extreme version 
called “unihemispheric sleep,” one hemisphere may appear completely awake
while the other is in deep sleep. Take bottlenose dolphins. Their breathing is consciously controlled, and they must surface for air every 
few minutes or they’ll drown. When they have a newborn calf, they must
actually swim nonstop for weeks in order to keep it safe. So dolphins sleep unihemispherically,
with just one hemisphere at a time. This allows them to continue swimming
and breathing while snoozing. Other marine mammals also
need asymmetrical sleep. Fur seals might spend weeks on end 
migrating at sea. They slip into unihemispheric sleep
while floating horizontally, holding their nostrils above the surface,
closing their upward-facing eye, and keeping their
downward-facing eye open. This may help them stay alert
to threats from the depths. Similar pressures keep birds
partially awake. Mallard ducks sleep in groups, but some
must inevitably be on the peripheries. Those ducks spend more time 
in unihemispheric sleep, with their outward-facing eyes open and their corresponding
brain hemispheres more active. Other birds have been shown to catch z’s
in midair migration. While undertaking non-stop transoceanic 
flights of up to 10 days, frigatebirds either sleep with one
or both hemispheres at a time. They do so in seconds-long bursts,
usually while riding air currents. But the frigatebirds still sleep 
less than 8% of what they would on land, suggesting a great tolerance
for sleep deprivation. It’s currently unclear whether
asymmetrical sleep packs the same benefits as sleep 
in both hemispheres and how this varies across species. In one experiment, fur seals relied 
on asymmetrical sleep while being constantly stimulated. But in recovery, they showed 
a strong preference for sleep across both hemispheres, suggesting that it was more restorative 
for them. Dolphins, on the other hand, have been observed to maintain high levels
of alertness for at least five days. By switching which hemisphere is awake, they get several hours of deep sleep 
in each hemisphere throughout a 24-hour period. This may be why unihemispheric sleep alone
meets their needs. So, what about humans? Have you ever woken up groggy after
your first night in a new place? Part of your brain might’ve spent
the night only somewhat asleep. For decades, scientists have recognized
that participants sleep poorly their first night in the lab. It’s actually customary to toss
out that night’s data. In 2016, scientists discovered 
that this “first night effect” is a very subtle version 
of asymmetrical sleep in humans. They saw that, during the first night, participants experience deeper sleep
in their right hemisphere and lighter sleep in their left. When exposed to infrequent sounds, that lighter sleeping left hemisphere
showed greater bumps in activity. Participants also woke up and responded
to infrequent sounds faster during the first night than 
when experiencing deep sleep in both hemispheres 
during nights following. This suggests that, like other animals, humans use asymmetrical sleep
for vigilance, specifically in unfamiliar environments. So, while your hotel room is obviously
not trying to eat you and you’re not going to die 
if you don’t continue moving, your brain is still keeping you alert. Just in case.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When a person suffering from a sleep problem in a new place hears an infrequent sound, the person can
Options: A. respond faster, B. wake up faster, C. show a bump in brain activity in the left hemisphere, D. all of the above
Correct Option: D

Because it's a type of sleep deprivation, C. Because it's a rare type of sleep, D. Because it's a type of sleep disorder Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main purpose of asymmetrical sleep in humans? Options: A. To conserve energy, B. To stay alert to threats, C. To recover from sleep deprivation, D. To improve cognitive function Correct Option: None

Question 10: What is the main difference between asymmetrical sleep and unihemispheric sleep? Options: A. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of deep sleep, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of light sleep, B. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of sleep where one hemisphere is awake, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of sleep where both hemispheres are awake, C. Asymmetrical sleep is a type of sleep where parts of the brain are asleep, while unihemispheric sleep is a type of sleep where one hemisphere is asleep and the other is awake, D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Take a deep breath. In that single intake of air, your lungs swelled with roughly
25 sextillion molecules, ranging from compounds produced days ago, to those formed billions of years 
in the past. In fact, many of the molecules 
you’re breathing were likely exhaled by members 
of ancient civilizations and innumerable humans since. But what exactly are we all breathing? Roughly 78% of Earth’s atmosphere
is composed of nitrogen generated by volcanic activity 
deep beneath the planet’s crust. The next major ingredient is oxygen,
accounting for 21% of Earth’s air. While oxygen molecules have been around
as long as Earth’s oceans, oxygen gas didn’t appear until 
ocean dwelling microorganisms evolved to produce it. Finally, .93% of our air is argon, a molecule formed from the radioactive
decay of potassium in Earth’s atmosphere, crust, and core. Together, all these dry gases 
make up 99.93% of each breath you take. Depending on when and where you are,
the air may also contain some water vapor. But even more variable 
is that remaining .07%, which contains a world of possibilities. This small slice of air is composed
of numerous small particles including pollen, fungal spores, 
and liquid droplets, alongside trace gases
like methane and carbon dioxide. The specific cocktail of natural 
and man-made compounds changes dramatically from place to place. But no matter where you are, .07% of every breath you take 
likely contains man-made pollutants— potentially including toxic compounds 
that can cause lung disease, cancer, and even DNA damage. There’s a wide variety of known pollutants
but they all fall into two categories. The first are primary pollutants. These toxic compounds are directly emitted from a man-made 
or naturally occurring source. However, they don't always come
from the places you'd expect. Some large factories mostly generate 
water vapor, with only small quantities of pollutants 
mixed in. Conversely, burning wood or dung can 
create polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons; dangerous compounds that have been 
linked to several types of cancer, as well as long-term DNA damage. In all cases, pollutants interact with
regional weather patterns and topography, which can keep compounds local 
or spread them kilometers away. When these molecules travel 
through the air, a transformation occurs. Natural compounds called oxidants,
formed by oxygen and sunlight, break down the pollutants. Sometimes, these reactions make pollutants
more easily washed out by rain. But in other cases, they result 
in even more toxic secondary pollutants. For example, when factories burn coal, they release high concentrations
of sulfur oxides. These molecules oxidize to form sulfates, which condense with water vapor in the air
to form a blanket of fine particles that impair visibility 
and cause severe lung damage. This so-called sulfurous smog was 
well-known in 20th century London and continues to plague cities 
like Beijing. Since the advent of cars, another secondary pollutant 
has taken center stage. Exhaust from fossil fuel-burning vehicles
releases nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons which react to form ozone. And while some ozone 
in the upper atmosphere helps shield us from ultraviolet rays,
on the ground, this gas can form alongside secondary
particles and create photochemical smog. This brown fog can be found covering
densely packed cities, making seeing difficult 
and breathing hazardous. It also contributes to climate change
by trapping heat in the atmosphere. In recent decades, industrial activity
has contributed to a huge spike in various trace gas emissions, fundamentally changing the air 
we all breathe. Many places have already responded
with countermeasures. Most cars produced since the 1980′s 
are equipped with catalytic converters that reduce the emission 
of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides. And today, places like Beijing are
battling smog by electrifying 
their energy infrastructure and limiting automobile emissions 
altogether. But while moving away from fossil fuels 
is essential, there's no universal remedy
for air pollution. Different regions need to respond 
with unique regulations that account for their local pollutants. Because no matter where you live, 
we all share the same air.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Trace gases and aerosol particles makeup ____ percent of the total composition of the atmosphere.
Options: A. 0.3, B.  0.03, C.  0.07, D.  0.7
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of Earth's atmosphere is composed of nitrogen generated by volcanic activity? Options: A. 21%, B. 78%, C. 99.93%, D. 0.07% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary source of oxygen in the Earth's atmosphere? Options: A. Volcanic activity, B. Ocean dwelling microorganisms, C. Atmospheric decay of potassium, D. Human activity Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the percentage of air that contains a world of possibilities, including pollen, fungal spores, and liquid droplets? Options: A. 0.07%, B. 0.93%, C. 21%, D. 78% Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the secondary pollutant formed when factories burn coal, which causes severe lung damage? Options: A. Sulfur oxides, B. Sulfates, C. Photochemical smog, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary function of catalytic converters in cars? Options: A. To reduce the emission of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides, B. To increase the emission of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides, C. To reduce the emission of sulfur oxides, D. To increase the emission of sulfur oxides Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the brown fog that can be found covering densely packed cities, making seeing difficult and breathing hazardous? Options: A. Sulfurous smog, B. Photochemical smog, C. Sulfates, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the primary source of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons? Options: A. Burning coal, B. Burning wood or dung, C. Volcanic activity, D. Atmospheric decay of potassium Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the process by which natural compounds called oxidants break down pollutants? Options: A. Oxidation, B. Reduction, C. Condensation, D. Reaction Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the name of the gas that can form alongside secondary particles and create photochemical smog? Options: A. Ozone, B. Sulfur oxides, C. Sulfates, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary function of regulations in responding to air pollution? Options: A. To reduce the emission of pollutants, B. To increase the emission of pollutants, C. To account for local pollutants, D. To ignore local pollutants Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question asks about the percentage of air that contains a world of possibilities, including pollen, fungal spores, and liquid droplets, which is equivalent to the percentage of trace gases and aerosol particles in the atmosphere. The correct option in Question 3 is A. 0.07%, which matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. and liquid droplets, alongside trace gases
like methane and carbon dioxide. The specific cocktail of natural

likely contains man-made pollutants— potentially including toxic compounds 
that can cause lung disease, cancer, and even DNA damage. There’s a wide variety of known pollutants
but they all fall into two categories. The first are primary pollutants. These toxic compounds are directly emitted from a man-made 
or naturally occurring source. However, they don't always come

regional weather patterns and topography, which can keep compounds local 
or spread them kilometers away. When these molecules travel 
through the air, a transformation occurs. Natural compounds called oxidants,
formed by oxygen and sunlight, break down the pollutants. Sometimes, these reactions make pollutants
more easily washed out by rain. But in other cases, they result 
in even more toxic secondary pollutants. For example, when factories burn coal, they release high concentrations
of sulfur oxides. These molecules oxidize to form sulfates, which condense with water vapor in the air
to form a blanket of fine particles that impair visibility 
and cause severe lung damage. This so-called sulfurous smog was

has taken center stage. Exhaust from fossil fuel-burning vehicles
releases nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons which react to form ozone. And while some ozone 
in the upper atmosphere helps shield us from ultraviolet rays,
on the ground, this gas can form alongside secondary
particles and create photochemical smog. This brown fog can be found covering
densely packed cities, making seeing difficult 
and breathing hazardous. It also contributes to climate change
by trapping heat in the atmosphere. In recent decades, industrial activity
has contributed to a huge spike in various trace gas emissions, fundamentally changing the air 
we all breathe. Many places have already responded
with countermeasures. Most cars produced since the 1980′s 
are equipped with catalytic converters that reduce the emission 
of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides. And today, places like Beijing are
battling smog by electrifying 
their energy infrastructure and limiting automobile emissions 
altogether. But while moving away from fossil fuels 
is essential, there's no universal remedy
for air pollution. Different regions need to respond 
with unique regulations that account for their local pollutants. Because no matter where you live, 
we all share the same air.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What controls how far away a pollutant spreads from emission sources?
Options: A. weather patterns and topography, B. the ocean, C. railroads, D. people
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of Earth's atmosphere is composed of nitrogen generated by volcanic activity? Options: A. 21%, B. 78%, C. 99.93%, D. 0.07% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary source of oxygen in the Earth's atmosphere? Options: A. Volcanic activity, B. Ocean dwelling microorganisms, C. Atmospheric decay of potassium, D. Human activity Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the percentage of air that contains a world of possibilities, including pollen, fungal spores, and liquid droplets? Options: A. 0.07%, B. 0.93%, C. 21%, D. 78% Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the secondary pollutant formed when factories burn coal, which causes severe lung damage? Options: A. Sulfur oxides, B. Sulfates, C. Photochemical smog, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary function of catalytic converters in cars? Options: A. To reduce the emission of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides, B. To increase the emission of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides, C. To reduce the emission of sulfur oxides, D. To increase the emission of sulfur oxides Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the brown fog that can be found covering densely packed cities, making seeing difficult and breathing hazardous? Options: A. Sulfurous smog, B. Photochemical smog, C. Sulfates, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the primary source of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons? Options: A. Burning coal, B. Burning wood or dung, C. Volcanic activity, D. Atmospheric decay of potassium Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the process by which natural compounds called oxidants break down pollutants? Options: A. Oxidation, B. Reduction, C. Condensation, D. Reaction Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the name of the gas that can form alongside secondary particles and create photochemical smog? Options: A. Ozone, B. Sulfur oxides, C. Sulfates, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary function of regulations in responding to air pollution? Options: A. To reduce the emission of pollutants, B. To increase the emission of pollutants, C. To account for local pollutants, D. To ignore local pollutants Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Take a deep breath. In that single intake of air, your lungs swelled with roughly
25 sextillion molecules, ranging from compounds produced days ago, to those formed billions of years 
in the past. In fact, many of the molecules 
you’re breathing were likely exhaled by members 
of ancient civilizations and innumerable humans since. But what exactly are we all breathing? Roughly 78% of Earth’s atmosphere
is composed of nitrogen generated by volcanic activity 
deep beneath the planet’s crust. The next major ingredient is oxygen,
accounting for 21% of Earth’s air. While oxygen molecules have been around
as long as Earth’s oceans, oxygen gas didn’t appear until 
ocean dwelling microorganisms evolved to produce it. Finally, .93% of our air is argon, a molecule formed from the radioactive
decay of potassium in Earth’s atmosphere, crust, and core. Together, all these dry gases 
make up 99.93% of each breath you take. Depending on when and where you are,
the air may also contain some water vapor. But even more variable 
is that remaining .07%, which contains a world of possibilities. This small slice of air is composed
of numerous small particles including pollen, fungal spores, 
and liquid droplets, alongside trace gases
like methane and carbon dioxide. The specific cocktail of natural 
and man-made compounds changes dramatically from place to place. But no matter where you are, .07% of every breath you take 
likely contains man-made pollutants— potentially including toxic compounds 
that can cause lung disease, cancer, and even DNA damage. There’s a wide variety of known pollutants
but they all fall into two categories. The first are primary pollutants. These toxic compounds are directly emitted from a man-made 
or naturally occurring source. However, they don't always come
from the places you'd expect. Some large factories mostly generate 
water vapor, with only small quantities of pollutants 
mixed in. Conversely, burning wood or dung can 
create polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons; dangerous compounds that have been 
linked to several types of cancer, as well as long-term DNA damage. In all cases, pollutants interact with
regional weather patterns and topography, which can keep compounds local 
or spread them kilometers away. When these molecules travel 
through the air, a transformation occurs. Natural compounds called oxidants,
formed by oxygen and sunlight, break down the pollutants. Sometimes, these reactions make pollutants
more easily washed out by rain. But in other cases, they result 
in even more toxic secondary pollutants. For example, when factories burn coal, they release high concentrations
of sulfur oxides. These molecules oxidize to form sulfates, which condense with water vapor in the air
to form a blanket of fine particles that impair visibility 
and cause severe lung damage. This so-called sulfurous smog was 
well-known in 20th century London and continues to plague cities 
like Beijing. Since the advent of cars, another secondary pollutant 
has taken center stage. Exhaust from fossil fuel-burning vehicles
releases nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons which react to form ozone. And while some ozone 
in the upper atmosphere helps shield us from ultraviolet rays,
on the ground, this gas can form alongside secondary
particles and create photochemical smog. This brown fog can be found covering
densely packed cities, making seeing difficult 
and breathing hazardous. It also contributes to climate change
by trapping heat in the atmosphere. In recent decades, industrial activity
has contributed to a huge spike in various trace gas emissions, fundamentally changing the air 
we all breathe. Many places have already responded
with countermeasures. Most cars produced since the 1980′s 
are equipped with catalytic converters that reduce the emission 
of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides. And today, places like Beijing are
battling smog by electrifying 
their energy infrastructure and limiting automobile emissions 
altogether. But while moving away from fossil fuels 
is essential, there's no universal remedy
for air pollution. Different regions need to respond 
with unique regulations that account for their local pollutants. Because no matter where you live, 
we all share the same air.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Photochemical smog is made up of a mixture of what two major secondary pollutants?
Options: A. gases and carbon dioxide, B.  nitrogen and oxygen, C.  argon and hydrocarbons, D.   secondary particles and ozone
Correct Option: D

To increase the emission of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides, C. To reduce the emission of sulfur oxides, D. To increase the emission of sulfur oxides Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the brown fog that can be found covering densely packed cities, making seeing difficult and breathing hazardous? Options: A. Sulfurous smog, B. Photochemical smog, C. Sulfates, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the primary source of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons? Options: A. Burning coal, B. Burning wood or dung, C. Volcanic activity, D. Atmospheric decay of potassium Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the process by which natural compounds called oxidants break down pollutants? Options: A. Oxidation, B. Reduction, C. Condensation, D. Reaction Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the name of the gas that can form alongside secondary particles and create photochemical smog? Options: A. Ozone, B. Sulfur oxides, C. Sulfates, D. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary function of regulations in responding to air pollution? Options: A. To reduce the emission of pollutants, B. To increase the emission of pollutants, C. To account for local pollutants, D. To ignore local pollutants Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, if I had to choose one, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 9, but since it does not have the exact same question content and options as the ground truth MCQ, I will also consider Question 6.

Upon re-examining the generated MCQs, I noticed that Question 6 is actually the most similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, but it does not have the exact same options.

But then I noticed that Question 9 has an option that matches one of the correct options in the ground truth MCQ, which is ozone.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They’ve passed every test, cleared every
hurdle, jumped through every hoop. Now, all that remains is to unleash 
them on the world. But wait— what’s this? Ah, yes, there’s one more challenge. 
They must now across the valley of death. All new products must pass through 
here before they reach the market. Many never make it out, 
and sometimes that’s OK— if they don’t work, don’t fill a need, 
or for any number of other reasons. But inventions that could help address
massive global issues also face this risk. That’s because a technology’s potential
isn’t the only factor that determines whether it will succeed. The valley of death is especially risky 
for innovations involving complex physical objects 
as opposed to software, and for those in highly regulated
industries, like medicine, building materials, 
and transportation. Regulations and other obstacles 
aren’t inherently bad— they’re often designed
to keep people safe— but they do tend to scare off investors, and that’s what traps good ideas 
in the valley of death: their funding dries up before 
they can become profitable. One of the fields where this problem 
is most pressing today is zero-carbon technologies. They’re essential to our future because they will help us eliminate 
greenhouse gas emissions and stabilize our climate. But they also have features that make 
them particularly vulnerable in the valley of death. Let’s look at why that is, 
and how we can change it. All new technologies must go 
through a development phase before they can become profitable. For zero-carbon technologies, the costs of this phase are high,
the timelines are long, and, in spite of the good they can do, demand is often low because they can 
require big changes in both infrastructure 
and consumer behavior. For example, electric heat pumps
don’t burn fossil fuels and, when you factor in savings on energy use, are cost-competitive with gas furnaces, but homeowners only change their heating
and cooling systems every few decades. Direct air capture technologies, 
meanwhile, remove CO2 directly from the atmosphere. We need these technologies 
to reach our emissions goals, and several of them have already
been proven to work, but they’re at risk of getting trapped 
in the valley of death because they're expensive. This creates a vicious cycle because 
the best way to lower costs is by, well, practicing: 
making more of a product and refining it. But high initial costs 
scare off investors, and without their money, companies can’t continue to develop 
their technologies— and can't ultimately decrease costs. Fortunately, there’s a way
to break this cycle: governments can help close the gap, when private investors won’t fund
technologies with such a high potential 
for social benefit. This isn’t just theoretical: in the 1990s, 
functioning solar panels existed, but weren’t widely adopted 
because of their cost. To change this, Germany offered government
loans to companies creating solar panels, and legally obligated utility companies to buy electricity produced 
using renewable energy. The U.S. and China followed suit 
by financing major solar panel projects. The cost of solar has dropped 
almost 90% since 2009, making it much easier to adopt. A similar thing happened for wind energy: during the oil crisis of the 1970s,
Denmark invested in wind power and started taxing winds’ 
fossil fuel-based competitors. Other countries took similar steps, and as more wind power was
generated worldwide, the costs of this technology
dropped dramatically. These success stories tell us 
that government initiatives work— initiatives like boosting spending 
on research and development, offering tax and loan incentives 
to startups that want to develop 
zero-carbon technologies and consumers who want to buy them,
and putting a price on carbon emissions. We need governments
to do what they did for solar and wind for many more innovations. At the end of the day, 
ideas and inventions alone can’t solve our most daunting problems— policies and markets have to be shaped so the most promising technologies
can succeed.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The valley of death is __________.
Options: A. The place where outdated products are discarded, B. The phase before new products become profitable, C. The phase where ideas are trapped if the product already exists, D. Where products end up if their demand is low
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term used to describe the challenge that new products must face before they can reach the market? Options: A. The valley of death, B. The hurdle of innovation, C. The test of time, D. The cycle of development Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which field is most pressing in terms of the valley of death problem today? Options: A. Renewable energy, B. Zero-carbon technologies, C. Artificial intelligence, D. Biotechnology Correct Option: None
Question 3: What are the two main reasons why zero-carbon technologies are vulnerable in the valley of death? Options: A. High costs and low demand, B. Complex regulations and lack of funding, C. Long timelines and high risks, D. Low costs and high demand Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the vicious cycle that traps good ideas in the valley of death? Options: A. High costs scare off investors, and without funding, companies can't continue to develop their technologies, B. Low demand leads to high costs, which scare off investors, C. Complex regulations hinder innovation, leading to high costs, D. Lack of funding leads to low demand, resulting in high costs Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is one way to break the vicious cycle in the valley of death? Options: A. Governments can offer tax incentives to companies developing zero-carbon technologies, B. Governments can provide funding for research and development, C. Governments can help close the gap by providing loans to companies with high potential for social benefit, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What happened to the cost of solar panels after governments offered government loans and legally obligated utility companies to buy electricity produced using renewable energy? Options: A. The cost of solar panels increased by 50%, B. The cost of solar panels remained the same, C. The cost of solar panels dropped almost 90%, D. The cost of solar panels increased by 90% Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the outcome of Denmark's investment in wind power during the oil crisis of the 1970s? Options: A. The cost of wind power increased dramatically, B. The cost of wind power remained the same, C. The cost of wind power dropped dramatically, D. Wind power was not adopted in Denmark Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is one way governments can help shape markets to allow the most promising technologies to succeed? Options: A. By providing funding for research and development, B. By offering tax incentives to companies developing zero-carbon technologies, C. By putting a price on carbon emissions, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the term used to describe the need for governments to do what they did for solar and wind for many more innovations? Options: A. Shaping policies and markets, B. Boosting spending on research and development, C. Offering tax and loan incentives, D. Putting a price on carbon emissions Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of allowing the most promising technologies to succeed? Options: A. To increase greenhouse gas emissions, B. To stabilize the climate, C. To eliminate the valley of death, D. To reduce the cost of innovation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest match in terms of question intent and content. The ground truth MCQ asks for a definition of the "valley of death," and Question 1 asks for the term used to describe the challenge that new products must face before they can reach the market, which is essentially the same concept.

However, it's worth noting that the options provided in Question 1 do not exactly match the options in the ground truth MCQ. If the options in Question 1 were revised to match the options in the ground truth MCQ, it would be an even closer match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why don’t zero carbon technologies survive the valley of death?
Options: A. Their development cost is high and production timeline is long, B. There is low demand for them, C. They require big changes in infrastructure and consumer behavior, D. Any of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term used to describe the challenge that new products must face before they can reach the market? Options: A. The valley of death, B. The hurdle of innovation, C. The test of time, D. The cycle of development Correct Option: None

Question 3: What are the two main reasons why zero-carbon technologies are vulnerable in the valley of death? Options: A. High costs and low demand, B. Complex regulations and lack of funding, C. Long timelines and high risks, D. Low costs and high demand Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the vicious cycle that traps good ideas in the valley of death? Options: A. High costs scare off investors, and without funding, companies can't continue to develop their technologies, B. Low demand leads to high costs, which scare off investors, C. Complex regulations hinder innovation, leading to high costs, D. Lack of funding leads to low demand, resulting in high costs Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is one way to break the vicious cycle in the valley of death? Options: A. Governments can offer tax incentives to companies developing zero-carbon technologies, B. Governments can provide funding for research and development, C. Governments can help close the gap by providing loans to companies with high potential for social benefit, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What happened to the cost of solar panels after governments offered government loans and legally obligated utility companies to buy electricity produced using renewable energy? Options: A. The cost of solar panels increased by 50%, B. The cost of solar panels remained the same, C. The cost of solar panels dropped almost 90%, D. The cost of solar panels increased by 90% Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the outcome of Denmark's investment in wind power during the oil crisis of the 1970s? Options: A. The cost of wind power increased dramatically, B. The cost of wind power remained the same, C. The cost of wind power dropped dramatically, D. Wind power was not adopted in Denmark Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is one way governments can help shape markets to allow the most promising technologies to succeed? Options: A. By providing funding for research and development, B. By offering tax incentives to companies developing zero-carbon technologies, C. By putting a price on carbon emissions, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the term used to describe the need for governments to do what they did for solar and wind for many more innovations? Options: A. Shaping policies and markets, B. Boosting spending on research and development, C. Offering tax and loan incentives, D. Putting a price on carbon emissions Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of allowing the most promising technologies to succeed? Options: A. To increase greenhouse gas emissions, B. To stabilize the climate, C. To eliminate the valley of death, D. To reduce the cost of innovation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 3: What are the two main reasons why zero-carbon technologies are vulnerable in the valley of death? Options: A. High costs and low demand, B. Complex regulations and lack of funding, C. Long timelines and high risks, D. Low costs and high demand**

Although the question phrasing is not identical, the intent and content of Question 3 are closest to the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks why zero-carbon technologies don't survive the valley of death, and the correct answer is "any of the above" (high development cost, long production timeline, and low demand). Question 3 also addresses the vulnerabilities of zero-carbon technologies in the valley of death, and option A (high costs and low demand) aligns with two of the reasons mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is:

**3**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They’ve passed every test, cleared every
hurdle, jumped through every hoop. Now, all that remains is to unleash 
them on the world. But wait— what’s this? Ah, yes, there’s one more challenge. 
They must now across the valley of death. All new products must pass through 
here before they reach the market. Many never make it out, 
and sometimes that’s OK— if they don’t work, don’t fill a need, 
or for any number of other reasons. But inventions that could help address
massive global issues also face this risk. That’s because a technology’s potential
isn’t the only factor that determines whether it will succeed. The valley of death is especially risky 
for innovations involving complex physical objects 
as opposed to software, and for those in highly regulated
industries, like medicine, building materials, 
and transportation. Regulations and other obstacles 
aren’t inherently bad— they’re often designed
to keep people safe— but they do tend to scare off investors, and that’s what traps good ideas 
in the valley of death: their funding dries up before 
they can become profitable. One of the fields where this problem 
is most pressing today is zero-carbon technologies. They’re essential to our future because they will help us eliminate 
greenhouse gas emissions and stabilize our climate. But they also have features that make 
them particularly vulnerable in the valley of death. Let’s look at why that is, 
and how we can change it. All new technologies must go 
through a development phase before they can become profitable. For zero-carbon technologies, the costs of this phase are high,
the timelines are long, and, in spite of the good they can do, demand is often low because they can 
require big changes in both infrastructure 
and consumer behavior. For example, electric heat pumps
don’t burn fossil fuels and, when you factor in savings on energy use, are cost-competitive with gas furnaces, but homeowners only change their heating
and cooling systems every few decades. Direct air capture technologies, 
meanwhile, remove CO2 directly from the atmosphere. We need these technologies 
to reach our emissions goals, and several of them have already
been proven to work, but they’re at risk of getting trapped 
in the valley of death because they're expensive. This creates a vicious cycle because 
the best way to lower costs is by, well, practicing: 
making more of a product and refining it. But high initial costs 
scare off investors, and without their money, companies can’t continue to develop 
their technologies— and can't ultimately decrease costs. Fortunately, there’s a way
to break this cycle: governments can help close the gap, when private investors won’t fund
technologies with such a high potential 
for social benefit. This isn’t just theoretical: in the 1990s, 
functioning solar panels existed, but weren’t widely adopted 
because of their cost. To change this, Germany offered government
loans to companies creating solar panels, and legally obligated utility companies to buy electricity produced 
using renewable energy. The U.S. and China followed suit 
by financing major solar panel projects. The cost of solar has dropped 
almost 90% since 2009, making it much easier to adopt. A similar thing happened for wind energy: during the oil crisis of the 1970s,
Denmark invested in wind power and started taxing winds’ 
fossil fuel-based competitors. Other countries took similar steps, and as more wind power was
generated worldwide, the costs of this technology
dropped dramatically. These success stories tell us 
that government initiatives work— initiatives like boosting spending 
on research and development, offering tax and loan incentives 
to startups that want to develop 
zero-carbon technologies and consumers who want to buy them,
and putting a price on carbon emissions. We need governments
to do what they did for solar and wind for many more innovations. At the end of the day, 
ideas and inventions alone can’t solve our most daunting problems— policies and markets have to be shaped so the most promising technologies
can succeed.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who can fund the development of new products when private investors don’t?
Options: A. The consumers, B. Like-minded companies, C. The government, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Governments can provide funding for research and development, C. Governments can help close the gap by providing loans to companies with high potential for social benefit, D. All of the above Correct Option: None

The cost of solar panels increased by 90% Correct Option: None

The cost of wind power remained the same, C. The cost of wind power dropped dramatically, D. Wind power was not adopted in Denmark Correct Option: None

By offering tax incentives to companies developing zero-carbon technologies, C. By putting a price on carbon emissions, D. All of the above Correct Option: None

Boosting spending on research and development, C. Offering tax and loan incentives, D. Putting a price on carbon emissions Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Since 2009, the cost of solar power dropped by almost _________.
Options: A. 90%, B. 10%, C. 70%, D. 100%
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Satan, the beast crunching sinners’ bones
in his subterranean lair. Lucifer, the fallen angel raging 
against the established order. Mephistopheles, the trickster striking 
deals with unsuspecting humans. These three divergent devils are all based
on Satan of the Old Testament, an angelic member of God’s court 
who torments Job in the Book of Job. But unlike any of these literary devils, the Satan of the Bible was 
a relatively minor character, with scant information about his deeds 
or appearance. So how did he become the ultimate 
antagonist, with so many different forms? In the New Testament, 
Satan saw a little more action: tempting Jesus,
using demons to possess people, and finally appearing as a giant dragon 
who is cast into hell. This last image particularly inspired
medieval artists and writers, who depicted a scaled, shaggy-furred
creature with overgrown toenails. In Michael Pacher’s painting 
of St. Augustine and the Devil, the devil appears as an upright lizard— with a second miniature face 
glinting on his rear and. The epitome of these monster Satans appeared in Italian poet 
Dante Alighieri’s “Inferno.” Encased in the ninth circle of hell, Dante’s Satan is a three-headed,
bat-winged behemoth who feasts on sinners. But he’s also an object of pity: powerless as the panicked beating 
of his wings only encases him further in ice. The poem’s protagonist escapes from hell
by clambering over Satan’s body, and feels both disgust and sympathy
for the trapped beast— prompting the reader to consider
the pain of doing evil. By the Renaissance, the devil started
to assume a more human form. Artists painted him as a man 
with cloven hooves and curling horns inspired by Pan,
the Greek god of the wild. In his 1667 masterpiece “Paradise Lost,” English poet John Milton depicted
the devil as Lucifer, an angel who started a rebellion 
on the grounds that God is too powerful. Kicked out of heaven, 
this charismatic rebel becomes Satan, and declares that he’d rather rule in hell
than serve in heaven. Milton’s take inspired numerous depictions
of Lucifer as an ambiguous figure, rather than a purely evil one. Milton’s Lucifer later became an iconic
character for the Romantics of the 1800s, who saw him as a hero who defied higher
power in pursuit of essential truths, with tragic consequences. Meanwhile, in the German legend 
of Doctor Faust, which dates to the 16th century, we get a look at what happens 
when the devil comes to Earth. Faust, a dissatisfied scholar, pledges his soul to the devil
in exchange for bottomless pleasure. With the help 
of the devil’s messenger Mephistopheles, Faust quickly seizes 
women, power, and money— only to fall into the eternal fires 
of hell. Later versions of the story show
Mephistopheles in different lights. In Christopher Marlowe's account, a cynical Doctor Faustus is happy 
to strike a deal with Mephistopheles. In Johann Wolfgang van Goethe’s version, Mephistopheles tricks Faust
into a grisly deal. Today, a Faustian bargain refers 
to a trade that sacrifices integrity for short-term gains. In stagings of Goethe’s play, Mephistopheles appeared 
in red tights and cape. This version of the devil was often
played as a charming trickster— one that eventually paraded 
through comic books, advertising, and film in his red suit. These three takes on the devil 
are just the tip of the iceberg: the devil continues to stalk 
the public imagination to this day, tempting artists of all kinds 
to render him according to new and fantastical visions.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Satan first appears in the Biblical book titled
Options: A. Exodus, B. Chronicles, C. Job, D. Judges
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the origin of the concept of Satan in the Bible? Options: A. The Old Testament describes Satan as a fallen angel who torments Job., B. The New Testament introduces Satan as a demon who possesses people., C. The Book of Job is the only source of information about Satan in the Bible., D. The Bible does not mention Satan at all. Correct Option: None
Question 2: In the New Testament, what is one of the roles played by Satan? Options: A. Tempting Jesus in the wilderness., B. Possessing people with demons., C. Creating the world., D. Destroying the earth. Correct Option: None
Question 3: In Michael Pacher's painting of St. Augustine and the Devil, what is notable about the devil's appearance? Options: A. He has a second miniature face glinting on his rear., B. He is depicted as a serpent., C. He is shown as a shaggy-furred creature with overgrown toenails., D. He is not shown at all. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the Italian poet who depicted Satan as a three-headed, bat-winged behemoth in his poem "Inferno"? Options: A. Dante Alighieri, B. John Milton, C. Christopher Marlowe, D. Johann Wolfgang van Goethe Correct Option: None

A scholar pledges his soul to the devil in exchange for pleasure., C. A scholar is tempted by the devil and falls into sin., D. A scholar is punished by the devil for his sins. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the term used to describe a trade that sacrifices integrity for short-term gains? Options: A. Faustian bargain, B. Devil's deal, C. Lucifer's pact, D. Mephistopheles' trick Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Satan, the beast crunching sinners’ bones
in his subterranean lair. Lucifer, the fallen angel raging 
against the established order. Mephistopheles, the trickster striking 
deals with unsuspecting humans. These three divergent devils are all based
on Satan of the Old Testament, an angelic member of God’s court 
who torments Job in the Book of Job. But unlike any of these literary devils, the Satan of the Bible was 
a relatively minor character, with scant information about his deeds 
or appearance. So how did he become the ultimate 
antagonist, with so many different forms? In the New Testament, 
Satan saw a little more action: tempting Jesus,
using demons to possess people, and finally appearing as a giant dragon 
who is cast into hell. This last image particularly inspired
medieval artists and writers, who depicted a scaled, shaggy-furred
creature with overgrown toenails. In Michael Pacher’s painting 
of St. Augustine and the Devil, the devil appears as an upright lizard— with a second miniature face 
glinting on his rear and. The epitome of these monster Satans appeared in Italian poet 
Dante Alighieri’s “Inferno.” Encased in the ninth circle of hell, Dante’s Satan is a three-headed,
bat-winged behemoth who feasts on sinners. But he’s also an object of pity: powerless as the panicked beating 
of his wings only encases him further in ice. The poem’s protagonist escapes from hell
by clambering over Satan’s body, and feels both disgust and sympathy
for the trapped beast— prompting the reader to consider
the pain of doing evil. By the Renaissance, the devil started
to assume a more human form. Artists painted him as a man 
with cloven hooves and curling horns inspired by Pan,
the Greek god of the wild. In his 1667 masterpiece “Paradise Lost,” English poet John Milton depicted
the devil as Lucifer, an angel who started a rebellion 
on the grounds that God is too powerful. Kicked out of heaven, 
this charismatic rebel becomes Satan, and declares that he’d rather rule in hell
than serve in heaven. Milton’s take inspired numerous depictions
of Lucifer as an ambiguous figure, rather than a purely evil one. Milton’s Lucifer later became an iconic
character for the Romantics of the 1800s, who saw him as a hero who defied higher
power in pursuit of essential truths, with tragic consequences. Meanwhile, in the German legend 
of Doctor Faust, which dates to the 16th century, we get a look at what happens 
when the devil comes to Earth. Faust, a dissatisfied scholar, pledges his soul to the devil
in exchange for bottomless pleasure. With the help 
of the devil’s messenger Mephistopheles, Faust quickly seizes 
women, power, and money— only to fall into the eternal fires 
of hell. Later versions of the story show
Mephistopheles in different lights. In Christopher Marlowe's account, a cynical Doctor Faustus is happy 
to strike a deal with Mephistopheles. In Johann Wolfgang van Goethe’s version, Mephistopheles tricks Faust
into a grisly deal. Today, a Faustian bargain refers 
to a trade that sacrifices integrity for short-term gains. In stagings of Goethe’s play, Mephistopheles appeared 
in red tights and cape. This version of the devil was often
played as a charming trickster— one that eventually paraded 
through comic books, advertising, and film in his red suit. These three takes on the devil 
are just the tip of the iceberg: the devil continues to stalk 
the public imagination to this day, tempting artists of all kinds 
to render him according to new and fantastical visions.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the Christian New Testament, the Devil does the following
Options: A. possesses people through demons, B. fights as a giant dragon before being thrown into hell, C. tempts Jesus, D. all of the above
Correct Option: D

The New Testament introduces Satan as a demon who possesses people., C. The Book of Job is the only source of information about Satan in the Bible., D. The Bible does not mention Satan at all. Correct Option: None

Question 5: What is the main theme of John Milton's poem "Paradise Lost"? Options: A. The creation of the world., B. The fall of man., C. The rebellion of Lucifer against God., D. The story of Doctor Faust. Correct Option: None
Question 6: In the German legend of Doctor Faust, what is the main plot? Options: A. A scholar makes a deal with the devil to gain knowledge., B. A scholar pledges his soul to the devil in exchange for pleasure., C. A scholar is tempted by the devil and falls into sin., D. A scholar is punished by the devil for his sins. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the term used to describe a trade that sacrifices integrity for short-term gains? Options: A. Faustian bargain, B. Devil's deal, C. Lucifer's pact, D. Mephistopheles' trick Correct Option: None
Question 8: In stagings of Goethe's play, what is notable about the character of Mephistopheles? Options: A. He is depicted as a charming trickster., B. He is shown as a fearsome demon., C. He is played as a comedic character., D. He is not shown at all. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the significance of the devil's appearance in the public imagination? Options: A. He is a symbol of good., B. He is a symbol of evil., C. He is a symbol of temptation., D. He is a symbol of nothing. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the overall theme of the provided transcript? Options: A. The creation of the world., B. The fall of man., C. The nature of evil., D. The story of Doctor Faust. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Although Question 2 does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, it shares a similar intent and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the actions of the Devil in the Christian New Testament, while Question 2 asks about one of the roles played by Satan in the New Testament. Both questions have options that mention Satan's actions in the New Testament, such as tempting Jesus and possessing people with demons.

the public imagination to this day, tempting artists of all kinds 
to render him according to new and fantastical visions.

Correct Option: B

Options: A. a charismatic, yet tragic, fallen rebel against God, B. a clownish jokester out to trap people into selling their souls, C. an imaginary villain meant to frighten small children, D. a mindless monster trying to destroy the world

Question 6: In the German legend of Doctor Faust, what is the main plot? Options: A. A scholar makes a deal with the devil to gain knowledge., B. A scholar pledges his soul to the devil in exchange for pleasure., C. A scholar is tempted by the devil and falls into sin., D. A scholar is punished by the devil for his sins. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the term used to describe a trade that sacrifices integrity for short-term gains? Options: A. Faustian bargain, B. Devil's deal, C. Lucifer's pact, D. Mephistopheles' trick Correct Option: None
Question 8: In stagings of Goethe's play, what is notable about the character of Mephistopheles? Options: A. He is depicted as a charming trickster., B. He is shown as a fearsome demon., C. He is played as a comedic character., D. He is not shown at all. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the significance of the devil's appearance in the public imagination? Options: A. He is a symbol of good., B. He is a symbol of evil., C. He is a symbol of temptation., D. He is a symbol of nothing. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the overall theme of the provided transcript? Options: A. The creation of the world., B. The fall of man., C. The nature of evil., D. The story of Doctor Faust. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Fourteen Greenlands could fit in Africa, but you wouldn’t guess it
from most maps of the world. The fact is, every world map humans
have ever made is wrong. Actually, it’s impossible to make a map
of the world 100% right. No, not you, globe—
we know you’re accurate. Not you, Google Earth,
you’re just a digital globe. We're talking about flat maps, which,
let's face it, are way more convenient
for a lot of things. Anyway, as we were saying, it’s impossible to make a 100% accurate
flat map of a spherical planet. For a long time, people didn't even try. They just plonked places down in arbitrary
locations without any consistent scale. Then in 150 AD, the Greek mathematician
and astronomer Ptolemy systematically mapped the Earth on a grid and placed locations on the grid
according to coordinates, so maps could be checked against
others and replicated. Ptolemy built his grid out of lines
we still use today: 180 lines of latitude
and 360 lines of longitude. In spite of these advances,
people kept getting lost. Part of the problem was a— shall we say— incomplete understanding
of the world’s geography. But it was also just really difficult
to navigate using a map. Because the Earth is round, the shortest route from one place
to another is a path along a circle. If we draw this route on a flat map, it passes through every line of longitude
at a different angle. To follow the route,
you’d have to constantly shift the direction you're traveling. Any slight error would land
you in the wrong place. In 1569, Gerardus Mercator
fixed this problem. He created a world map proportioned so these curved navigational routes
would be straight, passing through every line
of longitude at the same angle and therefore allowing navigators
to set a constant bearing— in other words, travel in one direction—
for a whole journey. There was just one tiny hitch: to do this, he had to distort land masses
and bodies of water so those furthest
from the equator got larger and those closest
to the equator shrank. In spite of its inaccuracies, Mercator’s
map was very useful. In fact, it’s still widely used today,
including in online maps. But it’s still wrong! In 1925, the Goode Homolosine Projection
was created as— get this— an interrupted pseudo-cylindrical
equal area projection. What does that mean?
Not important. The point was to minimize
distortion for the entire world. The map can be land-oriented...
or ocean-oriented. Either way, the so-called orange peel map
isn’t very easy to read. The Dymaxion Projection by American
architect Buckminster Fuller in the 1940s is even better. Sorry,
did we say better? It’s not better if you want to understand
where things are in the world. It is better in the sense that there are
no visibly evident distortions of the land masses. Though if you wanted to know, say,
how far Brazil is from Nigeria, you won’t get any sense
of that from this map. The most accurate projection to date
is the AuthaGraph World Map designed by Japanese architect
Hajime Narukawa in 1999. The continents and oceans are almost
completely in proportion, and the map is rectangular,
just how we like it. Could this be the perfect map? Well... no. Since the Mercator works
for navigation and reads clearly, why bother with all these
whacky maps? Arno Peters argued that by enlarging
European and North American countries, the Mercator projection
gives white nations a sense of supremacy over non-white nations
closer to the equator. He adapted the Gall-Peters Projection,
which counteracts that particular problem, but the continents are still... stretched. Today, we rely on maps less and less
for navigation, but they still play a vital role
in education. Peters was definitely on to something: no matter what map we’re looking at, it’s a story told from the perspective
of the map’s creator that in turn shapes—perhaps unduly—
our perception of our world. Simple changes in map design, even changes that have nothing
to do with how we transfer a round Earth to a flat surface,
can completely shift our point of view.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the first person to use a grid and coordinates to make a map?
Options: A. Gerardus Mercator, B. Ptolemy, C. Copernicus, D. Arno Peters
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main issue with creating a 100% accurate flat map of the world? Options: A. The Earth is too big, B. The Earth is round, C. It's impossible to make a flat map of a spherical planet, D. Maps are too complicated Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who created the first systematic map of the Earth on a grid? Options: A. Gerardus Mercator, B. Ptolemy, C. Buckminster Fuller, D. Arno Peters Correct Option: None
Question 3: What problem did people face when using maps for navigation? Options: A. Maps were too small, B. Maps were too big, C. The shortest route from one place to another was not clear, D. Maps were too complicated Correct Option: None
Question 4: What did Gerardus Mercator do to fix the navigation problem? Options: A. He created a map with a grid, B. He created a map with a Mercator projection, C. He created a map with a Dymaxion projection, D. He created a map with a Gall-Peters projection Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the result of using the Mercator projection? Options: A. The map was completely accurate, B. The map was easy to read, C. The map distorted land masses and bodies of water, D. The map was not useful Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who created the Goode Homolosine Projection? Options: A. Gerardus Mercator, B. Buckminster Fuller, C. Arno Peters, D. Unknown Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the main issue with the Dymaxion Projection? Options: A. It is not accurate, B. It is not easy to read, C. It does not show the distance between countries, D. It is not useful for navigation Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who created the AuthaGraph World Map? Options: A. Gerardus Mercator, B. Buckminster Fuller, C. Arno Peters, D. Hajime Narukawa Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the main issue with the Mercator projection according to Arno Peters? Options: A. It is not accurate, B. It is not easy to read, C. It gives white nations a sense of supremacy over non-white nations, D. It is not useful for navigation Correct Option: None
Question 10: What role do maps still play in education? Options: A. They are no longer used, B. They are only used for navigation, C. They are used to shape our perception of the world, D. They are only used for decoration Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: Who created the first systematic map of the Earth on a grid? 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the person who created a map using a grid and coordinates, and both have similar options, including the correct answer, Ptolemy (B).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

can completely shift our point of view.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why is it that we don’t have a perfect map yet?
Options: A. No mapmaker has tried hard enough, B. We have been waiting for technology to improve, C. It is impossible to make a 2D map from a 3D structure, D. We do!
Correct Option: C
